instruction: What kinds of spectrum was used in the related study to estimate the soluble solids content (SSC) of 'Rocha' pears?
Output: In the related study, the visible spectrum and near-infrared spectrum was used in the related study to estimate the soluble solids content (SSC) of 'Rocha' pears.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the related study to estimate the soluble solids content (SSC) of 'Rocha' pears using spectrum?
Output: Partial least squares (PLS) methods were used for feature selection in the related study to estimate the soluble solids content (SSC) of 'Rocha' pears using spectrum.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of SpectraNet-32 in estimating the SSC of 'Rocha' pears using spectrum and how well did it perform compared to other methods?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of SpectraNet-32 in estimating the soluble solids content (SSC) of 'Rocha' pears was the root mean square error of prediction (RMSEP). SpectraNet-32 consistently outperformed other methods in several metrics. On average, it was 6.1% better than partial least squares (PLS) in terms of RMSEP (1.08 vs. 1.15%), 7.7% better in prediction gain (PG, 1.67 vs. 1.55), 3.6% better in the coefficient of determination (R2, 0.58 vs. 0.56), and 5.8% better in the coefficient of variation (CV%, 8.35 vs. 8.86).

instruction: How many different experimental method configurations were assessed in the related study to evaluate the performance of the SpectraNet-32 deep learning architecture in estimating the soluble solids content (SSC) of 'Rocha' pears?
Output: In the related study, a total of 23 different experimental method configurations were assessed to evaluate the performance of the SpectraNet-32 deep learning architecture in estimating the soluble solids content (SSC) of 'Rocha' pears.

instruction: How does the performance of the SpectraNet-32 deep learning architecture compare to traditional methods in estimating the soluble solids content (SSC) of 'Rocha' pears?
Output: The performance of the SpectraNet-32 deep learning architecture in estimating the soluble solids content (SSC) of 'Rocha' pears is superior to traditional methods. SpectraNet-32 consistently outperformed other methods, including partial least squares (PLS), multiple linear regression (MLR), support vector machine (SVM), and multi-layer perceptron (MLP), in several metrics. On average, SpectraNet-32 was 6.1% better than PLS in terms of the root mean square error of prediction (RMSEP), 7.7% better in prediction gain (PG), 3.6% better in the coefficient of determination (R2), and 5.8% better in the coefficient of variation (CV%).
